column2:
Yiddish
(in Romanized Spelling)
(Guide to how
this Dictionary spells
Yiddish with Roman letters)

column1: a boring person, an annoying person, a pest, a nag
a person who is often confused
Adar, the 6th month in the Jewish calendar
alef, 1st letter of the Yiddish alphabet
angle; corner; part (of a region); groin
aristocratic descent (a man of aristocratic descent)
baby dog, puppy, sweet little dog
beggar, bum, tramp; an ineffuctual person
blessing for a good occassion, the arrival of a holiday, or the first taste of fruit in a new season
bungler, ineffectual person, inept person; a person who is easily victimized (American Jewish)
cry, scream, shriek; hue and cry; emergency
decree, edict (in Imperial Russia, a proclamation of the tsar)
dibbuk, an evil soul of a dead person which resides in a living person, expelled only by magic
dish of mixed fruit and/or vegetables; stew; (colloq.) fuss, something that has gotten blown out of proportion and turned into a very big deal
esreg, citron, a fruit over which blessings are said during the Sukkoth holidy
Gadol or Godol (Hebrew "big" or "great", a Hebrew term used mostly by Haredi Litvish Jews to refer to the most revered rabbis of the
Galician (male), a Jew from the Galician region.
genius, brilliant man, Gaon, head of a Jewish academy,in Babylonia, between the 7th and 11th centuries A.D.
hallel, a hymn of praise recited on some holidays
head (of the table); place of honor
Jewish Labor Bund, socialist labor party
Kibuts (also Kibbutz), a large collective farm in Palestine/Israel
Kislev, third month of the Jewish calendar
kugel, a savory or sweet pudding made from either noodles, potatos or matzo
Levite (a descendent of the tribe of Levi)
liking, taste in or for something
Lord of the World; the Almighty; God in Heaven, Master of the Universe
match made for unmarried people, often leading to a marriage
melupim, the diacritic mark that is sometimes placed after a Yiddish vov
Midrash, a collection of post-Talmudic literature
Nissan, the 7th month of the Jewish calendar
non-Jewish boy; impudent boy, smart aleck; wild Jewish boy
one of the Thirty Six Good Men
onlooker; one who looks on and often offers unwanted advice or comments, especially at a card game; broadly : one who offers opinions
opponent of Hasidism (Today the term is loosely used by Hasidim to refer to European religious Orthodox Jews who are not Hasidic, although they are
Ov, the 11th mo. of the Jewish calendar
person without a definite occpation; idler
prayer quorum of ten male adults
prayer recited on the eve of Yom Kipur
purpose, aim, practical details of a matter, serious business, "brass tacks"
recluse, one who devotes himself to the study of the Jewish sacred books
round (of a dance), stake (in a game)
Sanhedrin, the supreme judicial body during and shortly after the Second Temple period
scholar, enlightened man, adherent of the Haskalah movement
sense, common sense, good sense; reason; intelligence, smarts; wit; tact, diplomacy
shames, assistant to the rabbi in a synagouge; beadle
shofar (the ram's horn blown on Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur)
shrine, the Ark of the Covenant (in which Moses placed the tablets of the Law)
Shvat, 5th month in the Jewish calendar
Shvues, a Jewish holiday celebrating the gathering of the first fruits, and the giving of the Torah to the Jews
smear; spread; bribe; the whole package, the entire deal
spell, a charm; magic; witchcraft, sorcery
state, standing, station (in life), circumstances, situation
Targem, an Aramaic translation of the Old Testament
teacher of children in a Jewish school
The Forward, a weekly Yiddish publication
Tishebov, the 9th day of Ov, a day of fasting in commemoration of the destruction of the 1st and 2nd Temples in Jerusalem
Tishre, 1st month of the Jewish calendar
train; draft of wind; move (in a game)
Tu Bishvat, the 15th day of Shebat, New Year's day for trees
unlucky person, luckless person, person with perpetual bad luck; clumsy person
Veader, the added month of the Jewish leap year (added after the month of Adar)
vov with the melupim diacritic mark after it, a letter in Yiddish (grammar)
vowel signs used in Hebrew and Yiddish (in general)
wig (traditional wig worn by observant Jewish women)
wise man (often used sarcastically, e.g. wise guy)
writer of current public affairs; pamphleteer; columnist
yud, with a khirek vowel sign below it
